facts.text: Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL, JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 266 of 1972.  Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of writ it the nature of habeas companypus , Naranarayan Gooptu,

facts.text: Petitioner was an employee of the Government of West Bengal in the Collectorate of Hooghly District at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHELAT, ACTING C.J., At all material times the petitioner was an employee of the Government of West Bengal in the Collectorate of Hooghly District.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on January 29, 1972 pursuant to detention order dated January 25, 1972 by District Magistrate, Hooghly under s.3(2) read with s.3(1) of MISA 1971.

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested on January 29, 1972 pursuant to the order of detention dated January 25, 1972 passed by the District Magistrate, Hooghly under s. 3 2  read with S. 3 1  of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 26 of 1971.

facts.text: Detention order passed to prevent petitioner from acting in any manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The said order was passed with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner on January 29, 1972, in connection with incidents on April 25, 1971, September 14, 1971, October 12, 1971 and January 19, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: He was served with grounds of detention on that very day. The said grounds of detention were in companynection with certain incidents alleged to have taken place on April 25, 1971, September 14, 1971, October 12, 1971 and January 19, 1972,

facts.text: Before detention order, petitioner and six others prosecuted for first two incidents based on FIR dated September 14, 1971 under s.143/506 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: as set out therein. Before the said order was issued, the petitioner and six others, also Government employees in Hooghly Collectorate, were prosecuted for their alleged parts in the first two incidents on the basis of the first information report dated September 14, 1971 under s. 143/506 of the Penal Code.

facts.text: Petitioner and others discharged by Magistrate on March 29, 1972 on police final report dated March 10, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: On March 29, 1972, they were discharged by the Magistrate on a final report of the police dated March 10, 1972. Purusant to the said order of detention, the petitioner was detain and is still in Hooghly jail.

facts.text: Petitioner detained in Hooghly jail pursuant to detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Purusant to the said order of detention, the petitioner was detain and is still in Hooghly jail.

facts.text: Mother of petitioner filed application No. 318 of 1972 in Calcutta High Court under s.491 CrPC challenging detention on vagueness and irrelevance.

anchor.surface_text: The mother of the petitioner thereafter filed an application No. 318 of 1972 in the High Court of Calcutta under s. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. In that application the petitioners detention was challenged only on two grounds, namely, vagueness of the grounds of detention and their irrelevance.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta dismissed application on May 29, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: On May 29, 1972, the High Court dismissed the said application.

facts.text: All steps required under the Act complied with in time and manner prescribed.

anchor.surface_text: The record before us shows that all the steps required under the Act have been taken and companyplied with in the time and manner prescribed by the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner's case referred to Advisory Board, which reported sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case was referred to the Advisory Board companystituted under the Act, which reported that there was sufficient cause for his detention.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on April 15, 1972 under s.12(1), directing detention to continue for three years from date of detention.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1972, the State Government, on receipt of the said report, companyfirmed the order of detention under s. 12 1  and directed that detention to companytinue for three years from the date of detention.

facts.text: Petitioner made representation to State Government on August 10, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The said order of companyfirmation was duly companymunicated to the detenu. The petitioner thereafter made his representation to the State Government on August 10, 1972,

facts.text: Representation not considered as writ petition was pending.

anchor.surface_text: that is to say, several months after reference of his case to the Board and the said order of companyfirmation. The said representation was number companysidered by the State Government as by that time this writ petition had already been filed and was pending before this Court.

facts.text: Maintenance of Internal Security Act passed on July 2, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed on July 2, 1971. Its long title shows that it was passed to provide for detention for the purpose of maintenance of internal security and matters companynected therewith.

facts.text: President issued proclamation of emergency on December 3, 1971 under Art.352.

anchor.surface_text: On December 3, 1971, the President issued a proclamation of emergency under Art. 352 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Defence of India Act on December 4, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On December 4, 1971, Parliament enacted the Defence of India Act, 42 of 1971.

facts.text: Petition amended on October 24, 1972 to urge additional grounds.

anchor.surface_text: On October 24, 1972, the petitioner applied for urging additional grounds of challenge and on liberty being granted to amend, the petition was amended.

facts.text: Hearing before Constitution Bench on November 17, 1972, November 21, 1972 and December 1, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The hearing of the case started before the Constitution Bench on November 17, 1972 and was heard on that day and again on November 21, 1972 and December 1, 1972.

facts.text: Case referred to larger bench due to contention on validity of s.17A requiring reconsideration of Gopalan v. Madras.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that a companytention was then raised as to the validity of s. 17A of the Act which provides for a period of detention for 21 months without companysulting an advisory board, which question, the Bench thought, required reconsideration of the decision in Gopalan v. Madras.

holdings.text: All steps required under the Act have been taken and complied with in the time and manner prescribed by the Act. No objection to the petitioner's detention on that ground can be validly taken.

anchor.surface_text: The record before us shows that all the steps required under the Act have been taken and companyplied with in the time and manner prescribed by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record confirms timely compliance with Act's procedural requirements including service of grounds, reference to Advisory Board, and confirmation; High Court previously dismissed vagueness and irrelevance claims.

holdings.text: The contention that s.17A confers unguided discretion on detaining authority violating Art.14 is not borne out; no discrimination or violation of Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel argued that by the use of the words may be detained in the first part of the section an unguided discretion has been companyferred on the detaining authority whether to take action under the more drastic provisions of this section or under s. 3 1  read with ss. 10 to 13

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10 qualified by 'save as otherwise provided'; s.17A non-obstante clause overrides; no choice between procedures leading to discrimination.

holdings.text: Cl.7 of Art.22 is an exception to the rule in cl.4(a); Parliament's power to enact detention law without advisory board limited by requirements of cl.7(a).

anchor.surface_text: Three questions would emerge from this companytention  1  whether cl.  7  is an exception to the rule laid down in cl.  4   2  whether Parliaments power to enact a detention law is limited by the requirements

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.4(a) lays general rule of advisory board for detention >3 months; cl.7 exception requiring Parliament to prescribe both circumstances and classes conjunctively; harmonious construction avoids nullifying safeguard.

holdings.text: Setting out verbatim the heads or subjects upon which Parliament can enact detention law does not mean compliance with requirements of cl.7(a).

anchor.surface_text: These very questions were companysidered in one form or another in Gopalan v. Madras 1  in companynection with s. 12 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere repetition of legislative entries renders cl.4(a) nugatory; cl.7(a) requires specific exceptional circumstances and classes of cases, not broad heads; overrules Gopalan majority.

holdings.text: Sec.17A of the Act has failed to comply with the requirement of cl.7(a) and has therefore to be declared bad as being inconsistent with that clause.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 17A of the Act, in our opinion, has failed to companyply with the requirement of cl.  7  a , and has therefore, to be declared bad as being inconsistent with that clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17A merely enumerates heads from entries without prescribing specific circumstances and classes conjunctively as required by Art.22(7)(a); applies rule from h3 and h4.

holdings.text: No need to decide other challenges to provisions of the Act or detention order under Arts.14,19,21 as unnecessary after holding on s.17A.

anchor.surface_text: However, in the view we have taken of s. 17A of the Act we need number go into them as in accordance with the practice followed by this Court we need number decide more than what is necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Practice of court to decide no more than necessary once dispositive issue resolved.

anchor.surface_text: reconsideration of the decision in Gopalan v. Madras.  1  The Constitution Bench thought, therefore, that the case should be referred to a larger bench, and that is how this case has come up before us for disposal. The Act was passed on July 2, 1971.

precedents.case_name: G. falsinghani v. Union of India

precedents.citation: Satwant Singh Sawhney v. D. Ramarathnam, Assistant Passport Officer, Government of India, New Delhi.  4

anchor.surface_text: G. falsinghani v. Union of India, 3  Satwant Singh Sawhney v. D. Ramarathnam, Assistant Passport Officer, Government of India, New Delhi.  4  The contention, however, is not borne out by the provisions of s. 10 and 17A (1) and (2). In the first place, s. 10 opens with the words save as otherwise expressly provide in this Act. These words mean that the section would apply only to cases not expressly provided for in the Act, that is to say that would not apply to cases under ss. 17 and 17A which deal cases otherwise expressly provided in the Act.

precedents.case_name: Satwant Singh Sawhney v. D. Ramarathnam

anchor.surface_text: Such a provision for a review and the intercession of an independent and impartial person reduced to a certain extent the rigour of s. 12 (1). No such review, which would be of a quasi judicial nature,  see Lakhanpal v. Union of India 2  is provided for in the impugned section 17A.

precedents.cited_proposition: review under preventive detention is quasi-judicial

anchor.surface_text: preventive detention, a purely protectional measure, which must necessarily proceed in all cases on suspicion or anticipation as. distinct from proof, Rex v. Halliday 1  and that in such laws it would be impossible to maintain the various circumstances to enumerate various classes of cases exhaustively for which a person should be detained for more than three months except in broad outline.

precedents.cited_proposition: preventive detention based on suspicion, not proof

anchor.surface_text: About a mouth before the Supreme Court delivered its judgment in Gopalam 1 the High Court of Calcutta in Sitendra Narain Ray Choudhury v. The Chief Secretary to the Government. of West Bengal  2   F. B. (4) (a) read with cl. 7 (a) of-Art. 22.

anchor.surface_text: and the Legal Remembrancer, State of West Bengal  1  The Corporation of Calcutta.  1  These decisions have laid down that this Court would review its earlier decisions if it is satisfied of its error or of the baneful effect such a decision would have on the general interest of the public or if it is inconsistent with the legal philosophy of our Constitution,

C. Cooper v. The Union of India.  2  Nevertheless, we have to bear in mind the accepted rule that earlier decisions are not to be upset except upon a clear compulsion especially when the legislature has acted upon-,

precedents.cited_proposition: Art 22 not self-contained code; must be read with Art 19
